To succeed on exams, pay attention & take notes word for word of what she says.

She's one of the nicest people on earth and really cares about her students. However, she is also kind of a mess of a professor. She clearly is very busy but she wasn't great with technology or planning, so the syllabus was worthless and class got cancelled a lot. Not a hard class and was sometimes very interesting. Put in some work, you'll be fine

Prof Watson is very knowledge of welfare state politics and you would learn a lot about different welfare systems from this class. Lots of readings but manageable and she's really caring and flexible with extensions on assignments. 3 exams each worth 25% and ~15 carmen quizzes make up the rest 25%. Not a hard course but you need to put in the work.

Dr. Watson is one of the best professors I've had at OSU. She was very effective at teaching about the welfare state from a global standpoint and gave me a much deeper understanding of the welfare state here in the US, which is something I believe we all need to understand. This is one of my only classes where I genuinely enjoyed the reading.
The class isn't difficult but Prof Watson was inconsistent and unfair in her grading.

Prof Watson is very kind and approachable. The class itself was not difficult and fairly interesting. However, it was pretty unorganized and did not stick to the syllabus whatsover. Quizzes are easy and open book and she gives you plenty of time to complete them. Exams are also lecture based and nothing out of the blue.

Professor Watson is so clearly passionate about the topic she's teaching and it comes across during lecture. Attendance at lecture wasn't mandatory but doing the readings and going to lecture made it really easy for me come exam time. Prof Watson was very accommodating when I needed it and overall a great teacher.

She was okay. 2 midterm exams (worth 60% total 30% for each. But if you do bad on the 1st exam she will let you change the weight to 20%  40%) attendance is a part of grade and there is no final exam,there is a debate. but you get to sign up to be either a debater(no paper), brief writer (7 page paper), or judge (7 page paper). Easy class.

She gets really excited when she talks, she is great about engaging students and having discussions while staying on topic, even with 60 students. She moved back due dates a lot, which was helpful. It was great that she let us choose whether we wanted to take an exam or write a paper. We could get away with not doing all the readings.

Dr. Watson is a great professor that truly cares about students and enjoys teaching. She is highly knowledgeable and passionate about the material. She made lectures and discussion interesting and fun. This is the second course I have taken with her and I learned a great deal in both. I highly recommend taking a course with her you won't regret it!
She is a very easy grader, if you come to the lectures you don't really need to do the readings. She friendly and enthusiastic, defiantly an expert in her field. I would take her again.
Professor is good. A is easy. And she is always there to ask your questions. But she has awful lectures . They're not coherent at all.

One of the best professor's I have encountered at OSU! She knows what she is talking about and the class is very interesting. I learned a great deal from her. She is also very helpful in office hours, cares about students, and wants you to do well. if you come to class, take notes, and read the course material there is no reason you can't succeed.

This professor and course were great! A fair amount of reading not to much. I didnt have to purchase a text book. The professor was very knowledgable about the course and she was very helpful during office hours. there were two midterms and a debate no final. she gave study guides for both midterms. the class was an eye opener.

Really great class, i took Welfare because i couldn't fit the class i really wanted in there but i am truly glad i took this class!  VERY eye opening class!  Sara Watson is a very great teacher who knows everything about welfare and politics in Europe.  I highly encourage this class and I highly encourage taking this teacher. 2 midterms and debate

If you are white, male, conservative and rich do not take this class. Prof. Watson is very nice, but has one of the most warped ideas of how the Welfare State should be run. She constantly would slam Republicans and men for the problems in society. I walked out several times from outrage over her style of teaching.

Professor Watson has been one of my favorite professors while I have been at OSU. I took this PS class for my major but ended up really enjoying it. She doesn't take attendance, but because few people came the day before Thanksgiving, she took attendance that day and gave us extra credit. I would recommend this professor to a friend.

She is very interested in making sure the students understand the topics and how they react to the studies. She is objective yet structured in her teachings. Class was fun and stimulating. I would recommend this class and teacher to a friend.

The professor resists critique, possibly removing negative feedback about her class on here. Issues include outdated readings, ineffective group discussions, rigid lectures, and defensiveness to constructive class input. Not a very tough grader at all and the class is overall pretty easy, it just feels like a waste of credit hours at points.

Kara was a down to earth instructor. She made the class enjoyable and was willing to accommodate students. The workload for the class was flexible as well and she let us decide what our workload was going to be.

Amazing class, amazing professor. Lots of reading but you can get away with skipping a lot of it. Class is mostly discussion and very little lecture so attendance matters. She cares about the subject and her students and it shows. You have to go out of your way not to get an A.

Read from speaker notes the whole time. Had to curve tests by 18 points because people did so badly. Did not give us access to speaker notes so it was extremely hard to keep up and when you would ask to see them he refused. Genuinely I think he is a good guy but not a good teacher.

This class was definitely my least favorite I've taken at OSU. The way it was taught was just so bad. He read very quickly off of a transcript and did not let us see the transcript until after we essentially begged for it. We were constantly behind and had to miss material or cram in order to get everything done before our midterm.

This teacher is not quite a professor here, but solidly shouldn't be. His reading quizzes are hard even if you read the night before and he reads off a transcript. The transcript is NOT released so good luck keeping up with notes. The midterm and final were curved by a lot of points as they too were extremely hard. DO NOT TAKE!!!!!

Dr. Neblo is one of the kindest people I have ever met. Genuinely. It was the first time this course had been taught so it was a little disorganized but it was an honestly inspirational class. His lectures are phenomenal and his knowledge of the political process and democracy as a whole is amazing. A true genius and a thrill to learn from. 100/10.

This class was way too hard for a 2000 level. The lecture videos were only 10 ish minutes and didnt really help me understand anything. Quizzes were really difficult and I went over material multiple times. He didnt give me any feedback on my essays and gave me a really low grade, so I didnt have any way to improve for the final.

His online lectures are amazing & a lot of his quiz questions are phrased word for word on what he said in lecture. Ive never read any of the readings and Ive done fine on his quizzes. His midterm takes a lot of questions from the quizzes so WRITE THEM DOWN. If you do the lectures and take good notes (write exactly what he says) then youre good

Professor Neblo is a really good professor! He always emails back fast, and is very kind when emailing back. His exams are based on in depth responses which the readings are critical to getting a good grade! The quizzes are fair.

He genuinely wants students to do well, and his class is not impossible. That being said, the quizzes are rather difficult for a 2000 level class. The material isn't bad and he does provide guidance for the midterm and final, but still is a rather tough grader. Not a bad class, but certainly not an easy A.

The course consists of a heavy workload of readings! A lot of weekly readings; but it is absolutely possible to get through the class only listening to his lectures. Quizzes are very specific and can be considered hard and tough. Detailed grading for essays. No homework. I do have to say that the curve for this class is amazing though.
Such a stupid class. His videos are way too long. Time for quizzes are way too short. You will struggle. I find it hard to believe that a student wrote the good reviews on this site.

No book for the class, he posts the necessary readings on Carmen. However, it is possible to go the whole course without reading and still get an A. Focus on his lectures and you'll be fine. Take notes, it makes the midterm and final way easier. Overall, good prof, not too hard, just pay attention and you'll be fine!

For the online course he posts lectures online that go over and explain the readings. There are quite a few readings but weekly quizzes but they are not too difficult as long as you read. He gives you the essays for the exams before hand so its really up to you to just prepare well for them. Seems like an intelligent man.

This class is awful. Very difficult for a 2000 level class. Don't take this unless you want a headache. I'll admit I don't have much competency for theory based classes, but the material is boring and SO abstract. The final is also 45% of the overall grade and cumulative. Maybe take this course in person instead of online.

Professor Neblo is a good professor and makes otherwise bland topics interesting. With that said, he does not necessarily make it easy to do well. I did all the readings, watched the lectures, and took notes, and the quizzes were still very difficult. He does provide opportunities for extra credit though.

Prof Neblo is a lighthearted, happy guy. He is a brilliant man and genuinely interested in his work. He is always glad to help students and is very approachable. He explains topics pretty well. The readings are tough but his lectures are where you learn the most. Pop quizzes were pretty hard, and the partial open note tests were decently hard

Professor Neblo was amazing. He genuinely cared about the subject and was able to pass that on to his students. There was a lot of reading to keep up with, but the readings were interesting. Neblo would go on tangents, but they were always relevant to the readings and helped to expand our understanding of them.

Easily the best professor I've ever had. Nice, incredibly intelligent professor who genuinely cares about his students and wants them to learn and succeed. Be aware that it is a political Theory course, so it's going to be rooted in the readings, and the readings won't be as easy as textbook readings.
Goes off on tangents, class has a ton of reading and most of the time you don't get the main points because he doesn't explain things well.  Very smart guy, who is not that great of a teacher

He is one of the most likable, intelligent, and knowledgeable professors that I have had.  Take his class, go to his office hours, put a lot of work into your paper, and you will get a lot out of the class.  The quizzes will screw you because they're impossible, but do well on the paper and you'll do well in the class.

Interesting and engaged.  Always willing to help.  I took this class in the spring of 2004, but actually signed on just to make sure his rating was as high as he deserved.  Great professor...Great person.

Neblo was a terrific professor. He explained concepts very clearly and in-depth. I learned a lot from this course and found it to be very intellectually stimulating--so much that I chose to be a political theory minor. The discussions were good and the midterms were very fair. The quizzes were a bit challenging, but if you study, you will be fine.

He was helpful if you went to office hours. There was no book required for the class. The exams were partially open note. Almost every class, he does not tell you what he wants you to know. He just lets the conversation go where it may. Some of the really difficult readings you may not pick up on the main points unless he gives you a pop quiz.

Professor Neblo is obviously passionate about his field and is eager to express his passion to students.  Sometimes forgets that students don't know his books as well as he does, but offers opportunities for comments and suggestions which is awesome.  If you like a little philosophy and literature in your poli sci take this class :)
I thought they were unresponsive and dismissive. I also felt like they were not particularly knowledgeable. I would not take again.

The professor is very clear on what he wants from you. The quizzes unlock on Sunday and you have all week to do it. I enjoyed listening to his lectures as I found that none of the time was filler or wasted.

Module opens on Saturday and gives you till Friday to take quiz on lecture material. Lectures are kept short and the material is easy. Also has quizzes in the ebook (which are easy but take time) and a couple exams (set up similarly to quizzes). Like it because there isnt a ton of busy work and the lectures arent as boring as I expected.

Professer Gomaz's online classroom was set up in such a confusing and messed up way. Due to this work was never graded in a timely manner nor was the times that things were due consistent. I had to email them multiple time for missing due dates on assignments and about the wrong time things were due. I will never take another class by her

One of the most challenging and frustrating classes I've ever taken at OSU. Gomez uses unclear grading criteria and extremely subjective grading criteria when grading tests and essays. Essays prompts lack description and essays are expected to be extremely long. Not an easy A - beware.
I thought he was rude and condescending. I didn't think he was particularly knowledgeable. I would not recommend taking his course.

Took this class as an asynchronous online class but still got to see how amazing of a professor Chase was. He is a grad student but still explained everything we needed to know for the exams and quizzes very clearly. READ THE BOOK! Two extra credit opportunities and quizzes each week. Gives extra readings to better understand covered material.

Acs is an amazing professor in my personal opinion. Some do not like how slow he speaks in class but he wants to make sure everyone is able to understand and succeed. The course is graded by 2 exams and an optional extra credit paper/presentation on a topic you pick based on course content. I wish he taught more than 3 classes! 10/10!!!

> Class is useful for understanding how laws are created and implemented. Lectures were useful and well-organized.
> READING IS REQUIRED to pass the class. The midterms consist of T/F, multi choice, and shortanswer questions which directly reference readings. You NEED to reread.
> Grades: 30% Quizzes, 30% Midterm, 40% Final. 1-5 ex credit points

Professor Acs' assigned readings for each class, each of which were pretty easy. He had pop tophat quizzes for attendance, but you could miss a few without penalty. Two exams, each based on information in the lecture slides, but he rarely covered the slides during lecture and instead went off on random tangents.

I've had Acs for 3500 and 3115. Classes are incredibly boring; he's not the best lecturer and if you want a grade that's higher than a C, go to class, read everything, and study constantly. The only benefit is that there is a group project at the end of the semester, and he grades that leniently. Very mid.
The Professor is great, but he doesn't know how to explain the material and his classes and readings are boring.

The professor is knowledgeable, but there seems to be an assumption that students in this introductory-level class share his same level of knowledge. Lectures are painful to sit through and the readings are incredibly dull. Only four grades all semester.

Only graded on 4 assignments (30% Midterm, 30% Final, 20% Reading Quizzes, 20% Group Project). Extremely dry, boring content, kind of assumes everyone has an advanced level of knowledge even though there are no pre reqs to the class. Exams are unnecessarily difficult - both the midterm and final had to be curved by 20 points each.

Final grade is only based on two exams, reading quizzes, and a group project. The class is pretty difficult, he had to curve the midterm and final for a decent amount of points, think 10-20. The lectures can be boring but he does a decent job teaching, willing to answer questions, and is overall a pretty chill professor.
Class was super easy. One reading quiz a week which was common sense if you read the book. Curves the midterm and final a LOT. Highly recommend for a GE and he was super nice.

Lecture could be dry at times, but I still liked this class. Just a midterm and final (both administered online), final paper, and pop tophat quizzes based on the readings. He has students best interests at heart and everything was pretty straightforward.

Alex was an excellent lecturer. Insightful, even handed, and willing to answer questions and have a discussion. The class was based mostly on the midterms, final and paper, but he gave a generous curve and graded fairly. I really enjoyed this class.

This class is unnecessarily tedious and difficult. Endless amount of policies to choose from to study, and this prof seemingly picks the most boring topics possible. Doesn't give clear guidelines or content of exams, the quizzes don't even match the readings, and was pretentious with occasional out of pocket things said. -900/10, don't recommend.

This class was pretty easy, if you took high school gov you're off to a good start. I really liked Prof Acs, and though I probably could've gotten an A while skipping some lectures, I genuinely enjoyed being there. Classes kind of feel like a casual chat but he does teach the material well. Funny, chill, will lightly make fun of people.

Many questions are completely ambiguous or have conflicting information which makes the midterm luck-based. Everyone ran out of time, average was initially an 80%. Now it's a 78%, and we're confused whether he curved it down? No lecture recs, mandatory attendance, midterms open at 9AM for 1 hour, & no slides released until weeks after his lectures.

Professor Acs is a really great professor. He is clear about what his expectations are for your assignments. There are 2 midterms, 1 final. Lots of extra credit opportunity and he also curves almost all the exams. He is very smart and yet is easy to learn from as he explains things flawlessly. He is also funny and really nice!

Aces clearly loves the information he is teaching, the class had only three test- which he curved and extra credit was able to be given. There was a textbook- but I never bought it. I put this class on the back burner of 18 credit hours- not that it is easy, just never any commitment besides the three exams.

Your grade is determined based on the final and midterm exams. The exams are extremely hard he had to curve grades 12% because a lot of our class failed. Lectures are really boring. Wouldnt recommend this course or teacher. This intro class definitely hurt my gpa. Take with another professor if you can!

The only grade in the class is the midterm and final, which isn't an easy exam, but he does curve it! I would take it with someone else if possible, but have learned a lot. It is an intro level course, but is much harder than that. Other students in my class do not like him, but I do not mind him.

The only grade in the class is the midterm and final, which isn't an easy exam, but he does curve it! I would take it with someone else if possible, but have learned a lot. It is an intro level course, but is much harder than that.

He's a great guy who loves this topic, but you don't actually get through much content in the class because he talks about it all a little too much. Graded by three response papers, two exams, one final paper, and some reading quizzes. You really need to do the reading and it's very unclear exactly what he expects you to do in the papers.

Class is lecture heavy, though the slides are detailed so you can reread them. Her tests are a little harder so she grades on an easier system. Personally, I feel that she's pretty generous with her grading, and offers extra credit for attending classes. Very helpful if you go to her and ask specific questions about homework/final project.
Pretty easy class if you do the reading

Fair grader. There are no exams, just papers, but if you read the material and attend lectures, they're not difficult. There are weekly quizzes based on the readings, which average 15+ pages. There are two writing reflections, and he made the second optional. The lectures can be a little boring, but not the end of the world.

Reading heavy class, expect reading quizzes almost every single class. But the professor is nice, he cares about his students and gives a lot of advice for grad school. He's not a tough grader, overall if you read and go to class you'll pass.

I really enjoyed taking identity politics with Jose. He is super kind and explained the readings with such good detail and clarity. You can also tell he's very passionate about his work, which makes his lectures more enjoyable. He's also very funny, caring, and always willing to help students.
Amazing! He makes complicated subjects make so much sense. He is super understanding and not a very tough grader. Great to meet with outside of class because he is super helpful!

The readings can be a lot but that should be expected. They're very interesting and he fosters good class discussions and genuinely cares about his students and will ask for input on some class decisions. Well organized and mentally stimulating.

This class is certainly not easy, but Jose made it very enjoyable! You will be doing a lot of reading and researching so be prepared. My favorite part of this class is that he really was able to give a good look into the graduate school process. As someone applying to grad school I really loved this!
Kogan is an amazing professor. He is the most organized and knowledgeable professor I've ever had. He genuinely cares about the content and the students.

I absolutely loved his Law & Politics course. He provides so many opportunities for extra credit (just raising your hand) that your grade is a reflection of your effort. Daily reading quizzes aren't hard, very engaging lectures, and exams you can easily do well on. He gives real advice to students; every PoliSci major should take this course!

I'm not sure why others rated him so low... the majority of negative reviews are downright inaccurate evaluations. Kogan BY FAR is one of the best polisci professors at OSU with his extremely interesting and engaging lectures, great class structure (debate + guest speakers), and relevant reading assignments. He's knowledgeable and passionate!

I would not say he is a terrible teacher, he is not that bad but I wold say  pay attention and  make sure you understand because emailing him asking questions are not going to help. emailing him for help is a no go unless its a question about attendence or something along those line but question about midterms or final HE IS NOT HELPFUL.

Nice guy, interesting lectures, responds fast to emails, easy grader. Tons of extra credit and you can tell he wants you to do well. Midterm and final mcq is all from reading quizzes which are easy. Writing part of the midterm/final is long so start asap. 1 group project that you present in front of the class but grading is lax so don't stress

One of the best classes I have taken at OSU. The content was really interesting. This class has tons of extra credit. It is honestly really hard to get a bad grade. He had take home exams which he gave us two weeks to work on. He would also have multiple choice portions of the exams for which he would give us all the possible questions beforehand!

THE EXAMS ARE EASY: Multiple choice is a free 50%, and if you attempt each item on the rubric for the essay, you will receive another 25%.

Each time you participate in class or attend office hours, you receive one point of EXTRA CREDIT.

Best to go to office hours with a clear ask, he's hard to talk to.

Nobody understands politics better.
He literally might not be real.

Kogan is one of the most organized and intelligent professors I've taken thus far. It is fairly easy if you are interested in the material and do all of the daily readings. Exams are lengthy and tough but applicable and useful. I learned a lot.

I realized why he offers so much extra credit in class. He does in-class quizzes on Top Hat but manipulated the syllabus so that even if you have a valid excuse for missing the quiz and want to make it up you can't. The four "dropped quizzes" that he offers are a fraud, and my grade dropped after missing only two from an A to a B.

The information was engaging at times and the lectures were organized. Attendance is taken along with reading quizzes at the beginning of each class which could either hurt or help your grade. The exams were easy. The take-home questions required an in-depth ability to apply the material. Every time you speak you get a participation point.

Dr. Kogan is now of the most interesting and well-thought professors I have ever had. He is incredible knowledgeable and interested in his students success. The written exams are very long so make sure to start them early but he is a fairly gracious grader.
Spends all his time complaining online about unions and talking about how he deserves to make much more money than public school teachers.

Can't say enough good things about Kogan. Probably the most organized prof at OSU, responds in 2 minutes to emails, everything is very clear in syllabus. Can get extra cred for speaking in class, asks thought provoking questions. Exams are half take home, half online and aren't very hard. End of sem group project is engaging and fun. 10/10!

Very closed minded and hard to talk to. Some people just view themselves as too self important and he is one of them. You'll do well if you agree with him tho, just don't dare to have a differing opinion or outlook on a topic because MY GOD how dare you?!

Professor Kogan was the best professor I had during my time at OSU. He is really passionate about the subjects he lectures and keeps you engaged. His involvement in local politics and the examples he provides in class from his advocacy efforts prove that he cares about what he is teaching. 10/10!

Professor Kogan is really kind and extremely intelligent. He makes lectures easy to understand and always keeps them interesting. The downside of taking his class was that the readings are not easy and attending class is a must (otherwise your grade drops). The exams are also challenging and you have to plan ahead of time before starting them.

Vlad is a political scholar and is respected as such. You must show up to class everyday having read the assigned readings. Gives extra credit every time you go to office hours or participate in lecture.

Law & Politics class is a great option for anyone considering law school. There's lots of reading and exams (take home) take a few days to complete. This class is a lot of work but there are so many points available that you can miss a day or fail a quiz & get points elsewhere. It'll help you decide if law school is for you or not!

This man kogan is a absolute mad man do not take his class and Im saying this with a B. His group projects in a online setting is so stressful it feels like a dream thats how bad it is, his take home portion of exams are extremely long so do not try and do it the day before its due. Absolute nightmare and he does not care.

Super unaccommodating. I am in his class in the midst of the Covid-19 outbreak and somehow the class has gotten more annoying. He has a group project with 9 people so its impossible to meet and he doesn't give class time to do so and hasn' canceled it. There have also been at least 4 assignments not on the syllabus at all that he expects you to do.

He is unaccomodating. He has a clear class structure--great, but if you miss class, he refuses to let you make it up. Even for excused absences. Participation IS graded. Every single class. His "take-home" exam takes 7 hours to complete. If you miss tophat by 5 seconds he will not let you make it up. Dreaded going to class.

Professor is not understanding of outside circumstances that may require you to miss class, even if its excused. Participation is graded in a large lecture and if you miss Tophat he will not let you make it up. How to do the take home exams were not something ever taught in class and would only loosely apply to lectures.

Vlad has teaching down to a science. The course is a lot of work but if you do it all you should have no problem getting an A. He takes so many grades that its easy to bounce back if you do poorly on the reading quizzes. Participation is extra credit. Exams are takehome, a lot of work, but if you follow the rubric you'll get an A. Highly recommend

Vlad is a great professor. His course requires a decent amount of work, but it's very interesting. Some units were more stimulating than others , though. It's also worth noting that a lot of extra credit is given out. Overall, I would highly recommend this course.

Professor Kogan does not care about his students. He refuses to give students with disabilities accommodations. I would not take this class again. I am doing well in the class, but the lack of respect for students, especially students with disabilities, is discouraging and makes succeeding in the class difficult. Course content is interesting.

Although I have not yet completed the entire course, Professor Kogan's "Governing Urban America" is the best class I have taken at OSU. The class is straightforward. As long as you put in the effort, you will undoubtedly succeed. The lectures are highly informative and sometimes comedic. It is clear he loves to teach this class. Take this class!

One of the best classes I've taken at OSU. Participation and attendance matter for your grade. Class is very structured with reading quizzes (which you can do online) and a group project. He uses a lot of videos to aid his lectures, which I found helpful. Overall Vlad Kogan is a very good, straightforward teacher.

Dr. Kogan gives you a solid, no nonsense class. He is very smart, has interesting lectures, and his expectations are very clear. As long as you show up every day and pay attention you can easily get an A. Class is easy if you do everything, reading quizzes every day make up 25% of our grade and participation is another 20 so don't skip consistently
I really loved this class! Would highly recommend going on the police ride along. gives a lot of extra credit and tests are taken online

Prof. Kogan is a clear grader and an overall solid lecturer. Although the attendances are not mandatory, it is in your best interest to attend as many of the lectures as possible because they can give you a clearer view and a better understanding on the course material which are mainly cases that will be a huge part on the midterm and the final.

Class is fine, but his methods for grading attendance are draconian. If you miss just a couple of days (as in you don't do the online participation portions that correspond to the class) it can drop you a letter grade. Otherwise easy.

Very organized, which can't be said of a lot of professors. Have to read because of daily quizzes and participation on Top Hat. Midterm and Final are take-home and not graded harshly. Debate and legal brief at the end are a bit overhwhelming. If you go to class and ready, you should do well with him. Good class for those thinking about law school.

I think he's fairly straightforward as a professor. There's a lot of reading in this class and the take-home questions for the mid-term and final are time consuming, but the class intellectually is definitely worth it and he presents the material in a clear, structured way. Participation and reading quizzes are the key to doing really well

Reading quizzes every class, but once you get used to how he quizzes you they're a piece of cake. One group project that isn't too intense. Participation is a huge part of your grade, and the more you participate the more bonus you get. Exams take some time but they're not graded too hard. Interesting class and Vlad is a cool guy
Kogan is an awesome professor and class is always interesting. Do the readings and go to class and you'll be fine. Not to mention, he is fine as well so take the class.

Vlad is a great professor. I took both 4130 and 4127, and if I had time, I would have taken State Politics as well. Attendance and participation does matter. The reading isn't excessive, but it is required for the daily quizzes. Read the material, participate in class, and you'll do well. Among my most memorable professors at OSU.
Do not take if you are a student athlete, his participation and grading policies are very clear. If you don't come to every class, you might as well chop 5% off your grade.

Great professor. Attempts to not only add relevant multi-media content to each class but he also gives students the opportunity to network with Columbus community members relevant to the course. You'll have to work hard, especially on written portions of exams, but steady preparation should allow even the laziest student to get a "B" or higher.
He is a terrible teacher. Worst class ever taken!

Vlad is a pretty cool guy, and I felt he gave great lectures. The daily reading quizzes are super easy SO LONG AS you do all the readings. The midterm and Final each have 2 parts: take home responses and in class multiple choice. You're given all the questions for the m.c. ahead of time. The take home portion take a decent amount of effort though.
Professor Kogan is a great professor. Lectures are very interesting and as long as you pay attention in class and do the readings this class is an easy A.

This class is not THAT difficult if you put the time in. You have to go to every class, there are daily reading quizzes. The reading quizzes aren't that hard, they're just tedious. But 50% of your grade is condensed in the last two weeks: group debate, ten page legal brief, take home questions for the final, & the final. Overwhelming in the end.

This was an interesting course to say the least. Professor Kogan is enthusiastic about teaching students and also immerses you into the subject material. He is teaching at an entirely new level at OSU. He plays videos and has guest speakers, lectures are never boring. There are daily quizzes though so don't miss any days!

he was okay. A lot of reading with online lecture videos. you have quizzes at the beginning of class. watch movie for 2 hours and then last hour is set aside for discussion questions. I think they should have another teacher for politics in film in tv. His idea of having a meaningful discussion concerning politics is dry. Overall, not hard to get A

Way too much reading! There are daily reading quizzes as well as specific questions on reading in midterms and final. Very dry material and oftentimes seemed to have nothing to do with the course. Expectations for the 5 papers required in the course did not match up with what was taught in class. Professor is rude and unhelpful.

Dr. Kogan was extremely unhelpful and unclear. His notes were not straight forward and his expectations were not consistent with the subject material. Do not recommend taking this course. Found Kogan very rude and unwilling to help students.

Kogan is by far my  favorite political science teacher that I have had at OSU. His classes are extremely organized, he is very clear as to what he expects on assignments. He answers emails almost immediately, and the workload is extremely manageable. His material is highly compelling and as long as you remain diligent, you will be successful.

Professor Kogan really gets a bad rap. He is a very nice guy who recognizes students who do the work. Skim the readings for the jist of it and highlight quotes to use for the writing exams and you will be fine. All exams were take home essays that were under 5 pages and one massive paper that wasn't really too bad.
Interesting class. Midterm and Final are not easy and his grading is harsh on exams. Projects are interesting and not hard. He brings in city officials to talk to class...overall good class.

The majority of this class was spent in dreadfully dull lectures, the man has a genuine interest in the content but the way he communicates it is very dry.  The class requires 2 books which would be useless if not for the midterms and the finals which are graded primarily on stuffing the papers with quotes. The class is good but he isn't.

State politics can be a bit dry, but Professor Kogan conveyed the information in an engaging way & was open to feedback. Material was well organized. Readings required for the take home essays, but the lectures really helped to clarify readings. Possible to earn extra credit. The assignments were reasonable and grading fair. An overall good course.

Dr Kogan lectured for most of the class and encouraged discussion for the end of class--participation was required. He is young and inexperienced as a professor but he is very helpful. His grading is fair, and he offers a good amount of extra credit. I found his lectures to be interesting and engaging.

As a political science student, this was the 8th political science class I took at OSU. It was by far the worst of them all. He is not clear on what he wants from students on assignments, and grades harshly. I  have never appealed a grade in my entire college career but appealed every one in this class. I would avoid any class with this guy.

Extremely tough grader for not expressing expectations. Attendance/participation mandatory. Reading incomprehensibly difficult in large quantities. Teaches/grades like it's a grad school class. The dept. had to come in & whole class expressed dissatisfaction. Take-home midterm & final is a paper, which sounds easy but is NOT. AVOID at all costs!

Dr Keshk is one of the best professors I have had at this school. I had him for two classes, Intro to Globalization and Intro to Intelligence, and he was great. Attendance was rarely mandatory, but his lectures were very interesting. Very few papers with lots of time to write them, I don't think I read a single page and passed both with an A.
gave me a b+ on my final and his feedback was: good. do not recommend

Interesting class if you participate. He talks a lot but he's a smart guy and you can learn a lot from him. Dont bother buying the textbook you never use it. Also do the extra credit papers even if you dont think you'll need it, they are free points and very easy. He has some biased takes and again talks a lot but all in all a good professor.
Best professor I have ever had!

You're graded on five assignments. Biggest piece of advice is do the extra credit and submit the SEI because that is how I got an A. I had polite email correspondence with him but I probably would not take his class in person. The content is very straightforward and he sends quality reminder emails. Don't always trust RMP reviews :)
Tough grading and rude communication from the professor make this a challenging class. Luckily, Unstuck ai and the course textbook can help students stay on top of the material.
Guy's a well-paid yappitron. He's like one of those over-confident profs but presents clear anecdotal data like they're pure facts. Entertaining class tho.

Keshk was okay, he didn't do office hours only meet by appointment. Lectures were PDF's so you have to read and teach yourself. Practice the R software. You're only graded on 4 assignments and a final exam, one of the assignments is optional/EC. The math isn't hard, just basic arithmetic. I wouldn't take him again because of his hands-off style.

Does not take attendance, nor is it graded. The class primarily consisted of him talking about the topic for a while and then just rambling until he got tired and then would let the class out early. As far as mandatory assignments there are 2 short papers and one final 4-page paper but then you can do up to 4 short 1-page papers for extra credit.

Although this was an online class I believe it is obvious that Professor Keshk doesn't care to much about the class as the work done to set up the class is minimal and how you take the quizzes and tests is done in a very lazy fashion.

class always ends early. lectures aren't really over anything important to the class, but the subject is super easy to grasp on your own. 2 short papers and one final 4 page paper - really easy to do. class is honestly just him talking about random things until he looses track and calls it for the day. he's funny though so kinda interesting.

Only 3 papers. Class is just him discussing some world issue he thinks is interesting and does not cover actual material. There is no rubric to papers, does not provide insightful feedback but not hard to get a B or A. Lectures are boring, and he tries to be humorous with witty jokes. Class is not mandatory but he takes attendance for points.

Attendance is not mandatory, but you will miss a lesson segment if you don't attend. Only 4 assignments- not hard, but do not except him to be accessible after class. Ends class 20 minutes early always which is a plus, but also tends to get behind. Exam was not hard, all you need is to show up and take notes and you'll be fine. Thinks he's funny...
Took him twice. Very knowledgeable, wry humor. Statistics class is difficult information but provided very plainly. Makes theories make sense.

He's blah, and I wouldn't take his class to learn information. Most lectures just become discussions, and you could get a B pretty easily just not being dumb, but you can also get a B trying/showing up to every lecture, so it's really not worth it. He doesn't give good feedback and his humor is meh, but at leastyou won't fail with minimal effort.

The professor seems like a nice guy, but his method of teaching and grading makes it very hard to pass. The assignments are posted via a quiz, which is put under the strictest settings possible to "avoid cheating," but is hard to understand what part of the assignment it's asking about. Be assertive and tell him when you shouldn't  loose points.
He's a great teacher and knows what he's doing. Bunch of extra credit and not a tough grader. I would definitely take his class again.

Dr. Keshk is one of my favorite professors. He values communication and discussion, and their result is always inspirational. Take this course if you want to have a good start in your academic career in world development.

Talks to a silent class most of the time but people who are actually interested in their majors participate in the discussion. If you enjoy International Studies take this class, you get to have many interesting conversations and as long as you structure your essays right, your grade will be fine.

"Dr." Keshk is rude, thoughtless, and unworthy of the title professor. He allows carmen to grade assignments, and is unwilling to change mistakes carmen made. I went through a grade appeal process because he tried to fail me. According to him, I scored a 52% in his class, but according to the appeal process, I scored a 97%. Don't take his classes.
Actually the worst professor and could care less about the students success
Class material and lectures are presented through PDF. Instructor has limited office hours for assistance.
He is super rude when communicating, grades unecessarily hard. The class is "taught" through PDFs. DO NOT TAKE !!!!!

Dr. Keshk is always a pleasure to have as a professor. Attendance is not mandatory and the class is mainly group discussion about topics that he'll bring up. 3 papers, 2-3 pages each except for final which is 3-5. Clear grading criteria so just follow the instructions!

Easy class. Just do the module's lectures and the assignment follow directly from them. Exam was difficult, but not impossible. Anyone complaining that this is a tough math class must must have not finished elementary school. R Studio software used, can be intimidating but Dr. Keshk's notes are clear and you really have to practice to get it.

Straight forward class. Three papers, short, easy, just have to give your opinion and support them. I do not know why people say attendance counts, he said it doesn't and that what Carmen says about your attendance grade is not valid. Show up, listen, should be the easy class. The bad reviews must be from students who didn't attend the class.

You'll be teaching yourself everything in this online course with Keshk. There are only five assignments (assignments 1-4 and the final) that are 100 pts each; carmen grades your submissions, so follow his directions carefully because he will not review your work. His "lectures" are extensive PDFS, so prioritize your reading or you will not pass.

I had Dr. Keshk for Intro to Intelligence and Id say it was a great class. Grades were based on 3 papers, one of which is the final, and then participation, with an option to do mini papers for extra credit. If you make a good argument in your paper and talk a couple times, will def give you an A

What an appalling prof. Graded on like four things. Incredibly rude. In the online version of the course, he just gives us super long PDFs to read as his 'lectures'. Would recommend dropping out of Ohio State before having him as a prof. Stay away at all costs. Switch your major if you have to. He needs to be fired, immediately.

Absolutely awful, he should be investigated by his department. I've never seen teacher care so little about a student's success in his class. He simply does not care about his job and is more focused on his research. Avoid at all costs or wait till another teacher teaches it. I'd honestly drop out than have to take him lol
Does not provide feedback and is very, very rude.

I would like to describe myself as a student who always has good relationships with their professors and communicates well. Omar Keshk was not one of them. He doesn't even try to teach the matter and good luck passing. I emailed him in regards to questions about the final that he was not clear on, he was so rude. Do not take him.
just dont. this guy is the biggest joke of a teacher when he doesnt actually teach a thing.

1. There are no lectures. The only form of teaching is reading his typo-filled long PDF documents and teaching yourself. 2. He grades off 5 assignments that get heavier in weight each time, but he wont let you see your results other than the grade. 3. He still didnt know when the final would be 2 weeks before. 4. He goes out of his way to be rude

Im a straight A student and the lack of understanding has been unbelievable, especially during COVID. Would give him a 0 if i could. 93.5 and above for an A, but refused to correct answers in Carmen quizzes that were input correctly but counted as wrong because he had too many students. And only 5 assignments for the whole class.

Avoid at all costs. This class is offered with a different professor every fall, take it with him. Not an easy A, in fact Im not even sure an A is possible with him. Tough grader with zero rubric, feedback, criteria, nothing. Save yourself the headache and try actually learning this material with a different professor.

Literally just don't take this class with him. It's just him talking very fast and all over the place, nothing you could take notes on even if you tried. You won't learn anything. Grade is made up of three papers and participation (supposedly) but he didn't even let our class get those points and instead just made the papers worth more. Don't take.

Awful. Don't take him for intro to development if you're actually expecting an intro. His class is almost impossible to do well in without a substantial background in development already. The only assignments are three papers which he grades HARD. Incredibly hard. And he only gets more strict with each paper, but doesn't give clear criteria at all.

Couple papers for grades and that's it. Pretty easy class if you've had exposure to development before, but if not it may leave some things to be desired. He focuses a lot on the development of the Middle East/northern Africa because it's what he knows best. He's funny though and you'll learn a lot. Don't need to read the textbook.

only grades were 3 papers. each paper he grades harder on. In person class was just him going over articles or textbook chapters, and wanted a lot of discussion always during class. no lecture material besides conversation, didn't make the class that exciting. you have to know what you are talking about for the papers.

I took INTSTDS 3400 online, this was with COVID but it seems his online is the same even in regular times. If you can't teach yourself don't take this class. lectures are just PDFs you read. You don't need to do online book readings. There are only 4 assignments. Read & do the examples on lectures & you'll do well. He is not helpful and very blunt

Would not recommend taking this course online. The professor made little effort to accommodate for students having difficulty following his PDF lectures. There were no visual demonstrations nor did the professor attempt to make this an option. The material is difficult to grasp with it being fully online. If you need it for credit take it in person

Only 4 graded assignments, 1 extra credit opportunity, and the final. No midterm. He weights it in such a way that even if you cheat on the assignments, you can still end up with a C if you flop on the final. He let us out 20min early every class. Read the optional stuff if you're struggling with the content and/or ask Dr. Keshk for help

Dr. Keshk is very funny, he has the exact sense of humor that always gets to me. Personally I found the class material pretty easy as long as you pay attention, but it can be different for everyone. It depends on how analytic of a thinker you are. I enjoyed the class quite a bit though.

Dr. Keshk is an amazing individual and witty. There are no exams in the class and your grade will rely on how good you can write a paper! Lectures are super dry and can be hard not zone out of. No book and didn't really listen in class, papers are based off of research on your own mainly.
I'm not sure if he knows that we are not really engineering or data analysis majors, and it generally reminds me days I learned math. it's hard, Ican just say that. it's just data, math, programming.

He posted a ton of readings that most people stopped doing when they realized that the two short papers, 5-minute presentation, and one longer final paper were all on the same subject of your choice. Most people didn't go to lecture though he does take attendance. Knows a lot and told interesting personal stories.

Honestly all you're graded on is 3 papers and a presentation of the final paper. You do not need to show up for class. He takes attendance but not for a grade, and all you need to do is make sure you write the papers. Lectures are extremely dry and there is no point in reading or taking notes but he has really good one-liners. funny guy.

three papers made up most of the grade (one identifying a national security threat, then a solution, then a final paper) readings assigned and discussed in class but not necessary to write the paper funny kind of humor

Four assignments, weighted heavier each time and gets harder. Extra credit for 2.5pts. No midterm. One Final worth 35%. Covers material quickly. Take a lot of notes. Find a friend to help study with and share notes. Pay attention. Know material before he moves on. Ask a lot of questions. Having an understanding of calculus will help, not required.

Doctor Keshk's lecture style is extremely boring, but he tried to liven it up with participation. He told the class participation matters but did not take attendance for a grade, so you don't need to go to class really. You write 3 article responses throughout the semester, and if you follow his guide you'll be fine. The final paper is 5-6 pages.

I took Dr. Keshk's Intro to Intelligence course. I didn't learn very much about the material. He takes attendance every class so you should go but 95% of the lectures were basically in-class debates. Great guy, interesting debates. Only graded on 2 papers and a final paper that are mostly research based but need the book to cite for the papers.

No idea why this professor rates so low. There are only three grades in the course (all papers) and an opportunity to gain more points through participation. The professor assigns interesting articles predominantly about the Middle East and some regions of Africa and gives great lectures that are conversational base. I'd recommend!

This professor has a non-mandatory attendance policy but gives weird attendance grades anyway (I missed 2 classes and got a 67% on attendance). He admits to being an extremely hard grader and there were only 3 grades in the class, 2 papers and a final paper/presentation. He goes off track a lot in his lectures as well.

He hates grading tests and papers as much as I hate doing them, he cancelled my classes second midterm and didn't even have a final. Lectures can be boring, but he likes has no problem spending an entire class talking about current events in the middle east. He's also really bad at spelling. Easy A though.

Omar Keshk is one of the funniest professor I ever had at OSU. The course can be extremely difficult if you don't attend, so skipping is a big mistake. He tends to go fast during lecture, but will not mind whatsoever if you have a question. He has plenty of time slots available for office hours. He has a dry/dark humor, which is great!

Graded on 2 papers, a presentation, & final paper. Vague on what he wants (go to office hours) & the grade on papers doesn't match up to his feedback. Lectures give decent info but aren't necessarily related to assignments. Gives random attendance points but it isn't mandatory. I wouldn't recommend this professor and will be avoiding his classes

Five fairly straightforward homework assignments, with progressively more weight. If you go to class, pay any attention at all, and do your homework, you will get an A. He ended class twenty minutes early almost every day. Sometimes up to forty. There was an online textbook but it was free and I barely read it, to be honest.

Good teacher but he moves fast, make sure you ask if you don't understand something (he doesn't mind it). Pretty hands-on class, which was nice. I also just thought he was a cool person in general, has kind of a dry humor. Also, going to class is the only thing that'll help you do well on the homework.

Material is a little difficult, but nothing that can't be done. It's all understanding, and barely any memorization. He helps you through it though. Make you sure you are clear on the homework though because there are only four assignments and it's a major part of your grade.

Stats for Intstd and Polisci majors. At the beginning states it's stupid to make ppl memorize things they can just look up, then makes you memorize a bunch. Really entertaining and nice in lecture, but takes off stupid pts on hwk. Final was hard because he doesn't make it clear whats on there. If you go to class though you should pass.

I took Dr. Keshk's INTSTDS 3400H "Intro do Development". The class was small and I loved his lectures, but as a freshman I was definitely unprepared for the workload. Lots of reading (like 8 books), and he's a really tough grader on papers. Office hours are helpful. All in all the class was tough, but interesting & thought-provoking.

Although Dr. Keshk is funny, I found his class to be very difficult and quite boring. I went to every single lecture and struggled to understand the overall concepts. I also attended a few of his office hours, but still had issues understanding. I would not recommend this class to students who struggle in stats or computer programing.

I thought he'd be so hard. I had NO idea how to program in R. But I showed up & took great notes. He teaches & explains everything you need to know. Don't buy the book. He's funny, I enjoyed his lectures. I even ended up getting all A's or 100 on the HWs (take 5 hrs @ least).  I did not do 15 min of R a day like he asks. R was not even on the exam!

This class was unnecessarily difficult. Keshk was helpful when you went to office hours but class was boring and we only needed R for two assignments and learning to write program was extremely annoying.
You won't need the books if you attend the lectures and his humorous delivery makes them worth going to. He also covers everything on the hw and exams directly in class, easy and straightforward.

He is funny but at first comes off as if he doesn't really like teaching but I really enjoyed this class although his test were brutal. As long as you study you will do good but he wants you to be specific. You have to go to class. He says he doesn't take attendance but if you don't go, you won't pass. Take notes  and participate. You will do fine.
Amazing sense of humor. Encourages students to have there own opinions. Tests aren't hard if you take notes in class. Overall an excellent class

Interesting class, funny guy, but his exams are brutal and he tore apart papers. Don't take unless you already have a working knowledge of the third world. Very few grades in the class, very difficult, if not impossible to get an A. Doesn't use Carmen.

Professor Keshk is a funny and all around pleasant person to interact with. That being said he is in the wrong profession entirely. He is disorganized, unclear in his expectations and assignments, makes the simplest of topics complicated and his lectures are a joke. My greatest issue however, was his poorly maintained website. Just use Carmen!!!

Terribly boring class, hilarious professor. I hated stats so much I felt like I was going to die, but Dr. Keshk keeps lectures interesting and fun.  Don't bother with the textbook (I sold it back with the wrapping still on it and got an A), just go to class, take notes, and turn in assignments on time.

If you go to class and take notes, it's not that hard to get an A. Sometimes it's difficult to know what he is expecting from you on assignments. Do NOT bother buying the textbook, the formulas he uses are different and the material he covers does not match up with the textbook/assigned readings. It's a fairly dull class, though.

He was a great teacher for stats and made sure it wasn't boring. He made jokes and went very slow over the material. He has 4 assignments and a final, none of which are very hard. If you go to class and do the assignments the class is very easy. I thought he was a great teacher.

He's a great teacher and he's hilarious. That said, this class is not easy by any means. Go to all the classes and take notes and visit him during office hours. If you put in the effort you'll do fine.

The grades in the class are based on 4 assignments and a final exam. The assignments are somewhat difficult, but if you attend class and pay attention, it is all manageable. The examples Keshk gives in his lectures are crystal clear and anyone that says the concepts he teaches are difficult is a doofus and doesn't pay attention in class.

This was the worst professor I have ever had in my life!  His class was boring.   I asked him a question once and he told me to "google it."   I have read on here where people say he is funny.  Funny  doesn't help when you are trying to learn something so hard as statistics.

Prof Keshk was a tough teacher, no doubt, but if you go to class and pay attention, his class is a rewarding experience. I was an English major that needed a few math credits, so I took this class. It's not so much about computation as it is about presentation. After initially being terrified, I wound up really enjoying his class.

Dr. Keshk may be a bit disorganized on managing assignments and notes, but his lectures are why he does what he does best at. His explanations and examples were so clear and simplified that I understand him word for word. Do take your own notes, participate in class, and go beyond expectations on HW, and you will get a well-deserved A in his class.
Dr. Keshk asks a lot from his students.  He's really funny in class.  He is a tough grader and expects you to really take a lot away from his class.  If you put in the effort you will do well

Unfair grader with an unfair grading policy that makes his classes harder than they need to be. Doesn't use Carmen. Terrible writing and spelling skills. You're going to listen to a bunch of people in the class give their opinions on subjects that they know nothing about (in other words, a waste of time). Take the class with Wainwright.
doesnt use carmen which is annoying since you cant email your classmates. go to all the classes, take notes, he shows you how to do hw. not really clear on what was going to be on the exam.
A sadistic grader, stay away from this course if you don't want to learn a narrow interpretation of statistical methods from a third rate academic.

Dr. Keshk definitely did his best to make stats interesting to everyone. He's funny and very helpful if you need anything. I would definitely recommend this class to an IS major wanting to get an overview of statistics.

People complain about Professor Keshk, but that's just because he is very demanding and expects a lot from his students.  He sets clear goals at the beginning of the course, and is always willing to help keep students on track.  Take advantage of his willingness to review papers.  And ENJOY learning from someone as smart and dedicated as him.

He can be funny at times, but overall I would say I learned very little. He repeatedly confused economists, which drove me nuts and he never gave clear explanations for the essays. (which are what your entire grade is based on) After looking at the other ratings I was very disappointed. I would not recommend him.
One of my favorite professors so far.  He is funny, which is nice for a stats class, and he is very clear and helpful.  The book for this class was unnecessary, though he often implores you read it.

Just plain awesome.  He is clear, fair, and HILARIOUS.  He has one of the most awesome senses of humor of any professor.  He seems uptight and disrespectful at first but give him a chance and you will see how good it is for you 2 attend classes.  He is def one of the best.

One of my absolute favorite professors in college thus far. Kept the class engaged. If you skim the book you'll have enough material to adequately participate in discussion even if you're not a polisci major. follow his outline on the essays and memorize lists on the board for an A. make a friend in the class to compare notes (he writes illegibly).

Teacher is pretty cool, but does not give a lot of guidance on the assignments. You are pretty much expected to come to class and take notes word for word on what he says to do well. Text book is unnecessary! I got a better grade in this class than i anticipated, but it took a lot of work.

I loved having Dr. Keshk in class! He is excellent at facilitating good discussions and making his students think for themselves. He values participation highly, but you shouldn't be intimidated because he is pretty respectful of everyone's opionions. Very funny and laid back. I would definately reccommend him.

Awesome professor. Said that leaving true and false questions blank on exams makes him so angry that he goes and smacks his children. That was probably the most hilarious thing I have ever heard a professor say. And for that he is forever my favorite professor at OSU. Omar is the definition of a G.

Very easy class. Didn't go to class much and didn't look at the book, still got an A-. I just used google whenever I had questions on hw. The final was by far the easiest final I have ever taken. Would've gotten an A for the class but he doesn't believe in giving A's to people that don't get an A on all the hw. And unfortunately I got a B on one.

He is really great- makes lectures interesting and fun. Seems quite scary at first, and its important to try hard- he doesn't grade easy. Definitely worth working hard to experience a class of his. Learned a ton!

Dr. Keshk is definitely worth taking anytime you can. Although the material he covers is very difficult, his sense of humor makes the time fly and also allows for you to understand the material he is discussing. dont miss class because one time gone, and he doesnt re-cover the material from before.

I absolutely loved this class.  Omar is smart and hilarious.  The class is always interesting and participation is encouraged.  I just signed up for Omar's Int. Studies class because I enjoyed this class so much.

He is a fantastic professor.  It is important that you attend class.  If you go to class, then you never really have to pay attention to the book.  He teaches you everything you need to know.  Be prepared to work, but it is well worth it.

Dr. Keshk is a GREAT professor. He is informed, open-minded, encouraging, helpful and hilarious. I will take as many classes with him as possible- he is my favorite professor I have had yet. I absolutely loved everything about the class
Most boring class ever!

Dr. Keshk is a really good professor.  You do need to go to class though to understand the material.  His assignments take a lot of work, but nothing that is to hard.  He is a great professor, but that class is not something you can slack off on.  Just be prepared to work.

Dr. Keshk is a GREAT professor.  He is informed, open-minded, encouraging, helpful and hilarious.  I will take as many classes with him as possible- he is my favorite professor I have had yet.  I absolutely loved everything about the class but my only suggestion is  DO NOT buy the textbook he doesn't use it whatsoever in the class.

I took him twice (215 and 446) because he is interesting, but had a tough time with his grading... especially in stats! He grades very specifically, not for completeness. Funny guy, I learned a lot from IS 215 that has helped me throughout school!
Don't sign up unless you're prepared for a lot of reading and discussion. Worth the work though.
He does not come prepared for class, which is frustrating and annoying.
Omar Keshk talks a mean game but his class is full of hilarity and debate.

Class is very challenging and hard to understand if you haven't been expsosed to statistical analysis before. Dr.Keshk tries to ensure that the students learn the material and comprehend it... Homeworks can be challenge since there is no book and no quizzes throughout quarter...Overall Dr.Keshk is extremely nice and kind....Tough class though
Awesome professor

Honors class. No tests, just papers.  I thought his expectations were outrageous for an introductory level course.  Eight full length texts, wanted us to critique award winning authors, but none of us had an economics background. Probably a good teacher for an upper level course.  His personality was fine, his expectations were not.
Great prof. Down to earth guy, no nonsense aproach.

Professor Keshk had a general interest in students learning rather than their grades.  I learned a lot in the class and had fun as well.  Prof. Keshk is very funny and a good teacher.  Instead of having both a paper and a final exam at the end of the quarter, Prof. Keshk canceled the exam and took us to BW3's instead (on him).  What a great guy!

Had a great attitude and encouraged class participation. Memorize lists on the board for an A on the tests. Just watch out for the paper- write exactly what he asks of you. He's incredibly picky when it comes to grading those. I would reccomend taking a history or poli sci class before this just to get background knowledge.

Great Prof! Thorough lectures, and very interesting. Different point of view than most people take, but that made it interesting! Took a boring subject and made it interesting. Don't bother reading the book, his notes are golden. Above all, MEMORIZE THE LISTS! He lists things on the board, and they constitue 50% of his exams.
Made statistics fun
No Comments

I wouldn't ever take this class again, EVER. But Keshk is a good guy and he cut everyone a break knowing that statistic fundamentals are boring and no one actually wants to be there. If he taught a different class, I would probably take it. I'm sure he would do a decent job in a class with interesting course content.
One of my favorite classes ever taken at OSU.  He keeps you interested (awake) during the entire class period, even though the subject matter is pretty boring.  Funny guy.
thank you dr keshk
I DONT LIKE THIS PROFESSOR...he was unfair when it came to questions and he reads out of the book...

Condescending. Seemed more interested in 'being cool' and having the students like him than in being a good teacher. Played favorites: nice to dumb or opinionated students, tough on those who knew some facts. I would love to see a real statistician poke holes in his publications and life's work while he squirms.  Waste of your time.
No Comments

lectures were fun to go to. the first homework was frustrating, but after that, i hardly did any work. i studied like an hour for the midterm and final and got an A in class.  He tries to intimidate you at first, but he does it so you'll try hard on such easy material.  Whenever he repeats something like 20 times, write it down.
Funny and good at what he does.

this guy must curve like crazy. I got a D on my mid-term and got B's on the few homeworks that he assigned. I Felt like I did OK on the final, but a B overall in the class!? Had to have manipulated some numbers so everyone did well grade wise. If you are taking this class do not get discouraged. He seems to be kind when it comes to final grades.
funnniest teacher i've ever had

At first he is kind of intimidating, but then you realize he's really funny.  I had a scheduling conflict for the final in his class and another class.  He made a whole new final, and came to the university at a whole nother time just accomodate me.  That's just the type of guy he is.  I got a worse grade then I expected, but the class was such a great experience, that my B- didn't seem to matter so much.
No Comments
He was very engaging, funny, interested and knowledgable of this subject. I loved this class!
good class, funny teacher, the exams where straight forward. He did say that he was going to add a 20 page paper next quarter, but the class was not too difficult this quarter.

The class was interesting but it seemed to be very contradictive.  His tests were easy but getting participation points and getting him to remember your name can be another challenge.  When called up to do my oral presentation he said Mr. instead of Ms.  I would avoid this professor.

Sometimes he jokes around, sometimes he's serious.  Apparently saying f*** in class makes up for lack of teaching ability. If you try to go to him for help and don't understand right away he'll be a complete a**hole to you.

He is absolutely my favorite teacher at OSU.  He makes class fun and interesting, and always offers a view that the students haven't brought up.   I would tell everyone to try to take a class of his - you won't regret it
This was the best class i have ever taken...Definately recommended.
He is super funny!! The test were pretty easy if you attended lectures. He was really good about asking the students their opinions and was respectful. Take this class!!!
Keshk is a good guy, and a good teacher.

For as boring as a class as statistics is, this professor actually made me want to come to class just to see what kind of ridiculous**** he would say!  Everyday he gave good lectures, making sure everyone understood them.  Also an extremely flexible and helpful professor.  TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Funny guy.  Keeps the course challenging but not too difficult. Def. a good choice to take this class with him.
He is awesome. He is funny and a good professor.Take 443 with him if u r takin it.
He is horribly unclear, and doesn't take things seriously sometimes, and other times is horribly hardcore about things. He will insult you if you get something wrong.

This prof is ridiculous.  While his antics and anecdotes are amusing, his aim is to distract you from the topic to hide the fact that he is barely aware of anything besides the status quo.  Don't take his class if you want to think.

Thought that this class would be my hardest class this quarter, but I ended up getting my best grade in it! He's funny and tries to makes stats interstings as best he can. Pay attention and you'll do well!
Really funny, always made class enjoyable, was really understanding to students needs.  I was really scared to take the class but in the end it was the best class I had all quarter.
No Comments

This man is hilarious and you actually learn things in his class from debates.  Plus he doesn't get mad if you insult another student as long as you have a good reason. I called some kid a stupid tree-huggin hippie and he thought it was funny.
He's the best.  He's fair and helpful.  You're not just gonna get an A, but he makes it very possible for you to get an A.

Nothing like having 2 hour discussions in class about how the US will kick everyone's ass and Osama bin Laden being crazy. Priceless. Learn to write essays on exams, you'll do fine. He even let me take the exam early since I was going out of town.
had him for a while, had to leave for reasons that didn't concern the class....my Lord he's so funny. funny=sexy. Me wanty
Always available to answer questions; does not take himself too seriously
Lectures did not prepare for the test.  Berates people for slowing down his progress covering the course material.
This prof is the best prof I have ever had.  He is tough but fair, and will help you challenge yourself
No Comments

This prof is a blast.  Really funny and entertaining.  However, if you're not a fan of speaking up in class discussions, don't bother with his class.  He's all about the participation.  Oh, and a REALLY long paper, but it was worth it.
I really enjoyed this teacher.  He kept me laughing which in turn kept me entertained.  I had him for poli sci 145 and had a good quarter.
No Comments
Very sarcastic. Some people apparently find this entertaining.
Funniest prof ever!!! SO much fun in class
Very funny and interesting
No Comments
Why did Ohio State hire this guy? He doesn't help students at all!
He enjoys making himself seem intelligently superior over his students
One of the best

Professor Baum is one of the most caring professors at OSU. He is extremely willing to help outside of class and his lectures are incredibly interesting. If you have a chance to take one of his classes, do it!

Professor Baum was amazing. If you are seriously considering law school, I definitely recommend taking one of his classes. The entire class is very lecture and exam heavy, but if you truly engage in class and with the material, you will do just fine. I learned more in this class than I learned in any other political science classes combined.

Lawrence is a great guy and the best professor in this department. I have taken his two classes and I can say they will humble you. Not an easy A at all. Go for every class and write down every word he says. Highly recommend if you see law school in your future. It is very likely you will not get an A in this class. If that matters to you skip this

Great guy. Loved 4136 with him, so I took this class. Anyone with any interest in the Supreme Court should take him; you will learn so much. This class wasn't as good; I'd already learned about a lot of material in his other course. Still valuable research and writing skills. He provides copious guidelines for the paper. Do that and you'll be ok.

This is one of the most interesting classes I have ever taken. While the class is very difficult (beware if you just want a grade booster), he is really passionate about the subject and I learned a lot more about the Supreme Court. The papers are long and difficult to write (20 page final paper), but it will turn out alright if you put in the work!

If you have a chance to take a class with Dr. Baum. Do it. He is incredibly kind and cares so much for his students. Any and all of your questions will be answered in depth and he is very accommodating. The content can be a lot but if you follow the syllabus, you'll be fine

Dr. Baum is a fantastic professor. The final paper is long, but you will build up to it in your other two papers. By the end of the class you will have a comprehensive understanding of the court and a paper as a reference for your writing abilities. He does his best to connect with all students. I highly suggest taking even if you are not honors.

By far one of my favorite professors at OSU. His class had challenging material, but none of the assignments or exams are extremely difficult and he is great about implementing feedback. He also gave an easy extra credit assignment. I wish I had taken more classes with him while at OSU.

My favorite class I've ever taken was the one I took with him. He doesn't take attendance (though he notices those who show up) but GO TO CLASS. He's a great lecturer and if you know your lectures and cases you'll be fine . Sit towards the front to be one of Larry's favorites. You'll just want him to like you. It'll just make you feel good.

Dr. Baum was incredible, a 6/5. He always assumed he explained something wrong instead of getting mad at students for not understanding, he let us be curious without letting "poli sci kids" pull us off on a tangent, and he pulled from current events to teach material. The class was tough, lecture-heavy, and lots of reading for sure, but worth it.

Dr. Baum is my favorite professor I have had so far at OSU. He cares so much for his students and is very passionate about the content he teaches. This class is tough but he works with you and makes sure that you learn. Although I received a B I believe I learned more in his course than any of the others I took this term.

Professor Baum is one of the most kind, helpful professors I have ever had. The class is comprised of just three essays. They are 5, 10, and 20 pages and the 20 page is worth 70% of your grade. It seems intimidating, but he prepares you really well to do it and you will learn a ton. No attendance, but if you miss class you're screwed for the essays

Prof. Baum is the best professor Ive ever had at OSU as far as what I learned in the class  but the class was not easy! I loved the content, but there were only 3 exams, completely essay-based and timed. I had to rewatch lectures several times to get all the information at times. It was tough, but worth it. I feel like I know so much more now!
